turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in number 74-1222, Wolff against Rice.
Mr. Kammerlohr, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

This is a case of -- for the then Warden Wolff of the Nebraska Penitentiary who is no longer there, was the, is now a petitioner in this case, the case brought by Mr. David Rice under 28 U.S.C 2254 to primarily contest the admission at his trial of some dynamite, dynamite caps, tools, other paraphernalia and also later some dynamite particles found in his clothing at the police station.
Briefly how this case arouse, Your Honors, on the early morning hours of August 17, 1970.
The police station in Omaha, Nebraska received a 911 emergency call, they had woman who was screaming, sounded like perhaps she was being raped and a certain location was given.

Two patrol cars were dispatched, a third patrol car heard the message and also went to the location on Ohio Street in Omaha, Nebraska and upon entering the premises, Officer Larry Menard saw a suitcase on the floor which he moved slightly, and the suitcase exploded killing Officer Menard and injuring two other policemen and demolishing the house.

The -- about five days later on the 22 of August 1970, the police had, during those five days working round the clock trying to gather evidence and so on, had learned that from witnesses that the bomb had been planted by one Dwaine Peek who is a member of the National Committee to Combat Fascism, which was also considered -- said to be in a case, and referred to as an offshoot of the Black Panther Organization.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It does not inform any of the predicate for the issuance of the search warrant, does not it?
You are just giving background --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, just giving background to refresh --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- information in possession of the police at that time?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

And also, information in the -- as a result of this information and prior building of records over two-year period of newsletters, put out by the National Committee to Combat Fascism that they had advocated violence to police officers, including the killing of police officers.

With the -- plus another evidence, they had gathered that perhaps one Edward Poindexter who was a member of the National Committee and officer, President I believe of the National Committee to Combat Fascism and Dwaine Peek, arrest warrants were issued for those two members.
The police started on what they call a taskforce on the afternoon, late afternoon of August 22, first went to the headquarters of the National Committee to Combat Fascism.

They went through the headquarters looking for these two persons that they had a search warrant -- arrest warrant for and did not locate them. They then went to Poindexter’s home, did not locate him there.
They went to cousin, a cousin’s home of Dwaine Peek, cousin’s name are Frank and Will Peek and then they went to the home of David Rice, who is the respondent in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And up to this point, what warrants if any, did they have?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Up to this point, they had arrest warrants for Dwaine Peek and Edward Poindexter, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not for the, not for the respondent?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- up to that point?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: At this point.

The -- I would like to point out that they did not, I think the opinion in the United States Court of Appeals for the Eight Circuit, does a disservice to this case by saying, by comparing it to Langford versus Gilstone where some 300 non-related searches were made.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that Baltimore case?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
In this case, there are only three searches made before they arrived at the Rice premises and even those were connected.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did they search anything at the first two stops?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: They searched the premises at the headquarters, at the other two stops the record is not clear just what they did, they went there looking for them at least.
I believe at the one place, there was a police officer there already, who assured them that neither one of the defendants are on the -- the subjects were on the premises.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Just the pursuant to what Mr. Justice Stewart had mentioned, at that point the mission was to execute to serve an arrest warrant --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For two other people --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- for two people who are not involved in this case?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

They were all three members of the party, the National Committee to Combat Fascism, and -- which had been prior -- previously connected into the case by the fact that Dwaine Peek was said to have planted the bomb for the National Committee to Combat Fascism.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was said by whom?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: His sisters and Donald Peek a brother had given this information to the police.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that information been published, made public to the public generally?
It was a newspaper, was not it, or a publication?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: All the police officers were cognizant of this. Several witnesses had seen Dwaine Peek carrying a heavy suitcase and telling people, do not touch it, on the night before the -- the night before the bomb was planted.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that was Peek?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who was the subject of, one of the subjects, one of the two subjects of the arrest warrants?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct.

The -- upon arrival or some, late at night, maybe nine-thirty, ten o'clock at night that David Rice's premises, the lights were on, a television set was playing, they could see it through the door, the police knocked on the door and there was no response.
And at this time the -- two of the police officers decided they should go back and see if they could get a search warrant.

They left the other officers there to surround the house and the two officers went back to the police headquarters and drafted an affidavit and found themselves a magistrate, who incidentally in Nebraska, all magistrates are members of the Nebraska Bar Association in Good Standing, they presented the affidavit to the magistrate who issued the search warrant for the premises describing the exact address of David Rice’s premises and the things to be searched or to be seized.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What, what were they?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Dynamite, dynamite caps, pliers, pincher-nose pliers, those are the kind of -- maybe I should, it is in the appendix, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I believe it is on page ten of the appendix, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Wire is not -- it is not quite so explicit as you have indicated, as I read it.
Dynamite and illegal weapons, also the devices which might be used to construct weapons or explosive devices which could be used to cause injury to persons or damage the property, is that it?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, that is it, Your Honor.
It is not -- it does not say the pliers and the wires, I am sorry.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: It does say what you have indicated.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: In any -- in any case the police then with -- the two officers with the search warrant went back to the Rice premises and all the officers entered the premises and found the evidence, which is objected to in this case.
It was all in plain sight upon entering the premises.
They did not have to overturn anything or open any drawers or anything of that nature.
The Federal District, well, first the Supreme Court of Nebraska --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) they knew the police where there all this time, did not they, did not the police first wrap on the door?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And they knew the police were there?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: There was no one there inside the premises.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And when he went back?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Still no one inside the premises, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is what I am trying to get straight.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: They staked out the house?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: They staked out the house while they were gone.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And sent an officer to get the warrant that you just referred to on pages --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Two officers, to get the warrant of arrest and staked out the house.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the house was empty, as I understand it at all relevant times, although there were lights on in the house and I think a television set was turned on, is that correct?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor, that is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But nobody in the house?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No people in the house.
The -- before the actual trial, the respondent moved for suppression in the District Court of Douglas County, which is in Omaha.
The District Court denied suppression of the evidence.
The Supreme Court of Nebraska affirmed finding that the affidavit for search warrant was sufficient.
The Federal District Court in the 2254 case then found that the affidavit for search warrant was not sufficient.

We then had later, after that order was first -- that order of several months previous to the -- to another order which the Federal District Court later issued finding that there were not any other grounds either authorizing legal entry into the premises.

The United States Court of Appeals affirmed and we then petitioned this Court and are here and although I have a number of issues in my brief and in our petition for certiorari, I would like to primarily argue two main points which we would urge this Court to adopt and we would still like to rely of course on our other points in our case, should those be denied.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Kammerlohr, before you proceed, may I ask you is there -- do we have any papers filed here a copy of the opinion of the Supreme Court of Nebraska?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Can you tell me where?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I am sorry.
The Supreme Court of Nebraska, opinion does not appear -- the federal opinions are all I have in the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, that is what I thought.
But, I do not -- I cannot even see the citation of the, perhaps your colleague can find it --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I have the 188 Nebraska, 728 --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: That is Northwestern cited as 199 Northwestern 2nd 480.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: As I have alluded to -- alluded in my brief, this Court of course is very familiar with the arguments against the exclusionary rule and for the exclusionary rule and there has been dissatisfaction mentioned a number of times so that I do not intend to go into all of those various cases and try to tell the this Court the same things that you are very familiar with and take up your time and time of others here.
I do think I should mention, just briefly, why we do not feel that the; number one, the exclusionary rule should apply on officers or acting under a search warrant.
We would ask the clerk to modify the exclusionary rule to very least to that point.
The magistrate perhaps was the person who was wrong if anyone was wrong and issued a search warrant in this case.

I do not believe that we can blame or that the purposes of the exclusionary rule would be served if the purposes are to deter unlawful action of the police or they have tried to do what is right, they have gone to a lawyer magistrate and asked for a search warrant.

I don’t see how can there can be any possibility of deterrents to future cases, because it is the type of procedure we operate under, it is preemptory type writ, there is no way of having an immediate hearing to see if the writ is any good.
The police certainly would not be in a position every time they get a search warrant to question its validity.
We encourage the use of search warrants and I believe the imposition of the exclusionary rule would go more to discourage the use of search warrants than to encourage it.
So for those reasons and for that purpose of the exclusionary rule I would ask the Court to at least modify the exclusionary rule to that extent when officers are operating under search warrant.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Generally, I suppose you mean --?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Generally, I would ask in good -- when they are operating in good faith and think that they are following the law that the exclusionary rule serves no purpose and in that light generally, I might also say I know we are all interested in seeing that we have the preservation of freedom and privacy in this country, but the exclusionary rule as this Court well knows, does absolutely nothing to protect those who do not have any guilty evidence on their premises.

If the police should suddenly take it into their heads to become a Police State or Nazi-type State, the general public who does not have any guilty evidence on their premises where they have -- have absolutely no remedy under the exclusionary rule, they are not just protected.

The same is true when the police take it into their head to harass gamblers or house of prostitution or anything else where they do not want the evidence to used in the court, but they merely want to either gather the evidence to destroy it or they want to -- let them know that they are aware of their operations, the exclusionary rule does those people absolutely no good.
Now, we do not, we cannot measure of course --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I believe it could --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- you are talking about?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Because the alternative remedies that then suggest, I believe they could, Your Honor.
If we had --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) knock down doors and all that knocks down old constitutions, does it?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Unless we do provide a better remedy than the exclusionary rule, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not that they have been suggested necessarily as alternative remedies, they have been suggested as additional remedies, have they not?

Maybe the exclusionary rule only -- only serves to effectuate the Fourth Amendment in the context of a criminal trial, but other remedies are at least theoretically available to effectuate that constitutional provision in other contexts, i.e. civil lawsuits, Bivens; Bivens case, you are familiar with, are you not?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: The Bivens case --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is not an alternative to the exclusionary rule, it is an additional sanction, is it not?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
It is an additional -- 1983 cases -- I believe that was a probably a 1983 case, was it not?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: It was not.
Well, I believe that anyway that there is a remedy under 42 1983.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 1983, where the Bivens involved a Federal -- the Federal Government, that is the reason it was in 1983, but as to against state agents there might be 1983 remedies and these are not alternatives, they are additional remedies, are they not, under present state of the law?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: In a present state of the law, but I am just saying that those writers like Allan Oaks, Professor Oaks and Mr. Chief Justice Burger I believe dissented in Bivens to suggest that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) was not it?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: If we should move away from the exclusionary rule completely we should have an alternative remedy.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Those remedies, there is considerable question about their efficacy and practical value, but they are -- they are now there, are they not?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, they are.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You are not -- you are not suggesting or trying to invent addition -- anything that is not already there, are you?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I am not suggesting that we --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You are suggesting that we take away something, not that we add something, is that correct, from what is presently they are to effectuate the --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I am suggesting that the exclusionary rule does not do a thing for these certain classes that I was mentioning.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: And I am suggesting that we do add something --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They are already there, what would you add?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I would make a requirement that before the exclusionary rule be completely abandoned by this Court in all cases that the States must provide a tort remedy with a minimum recovery for the person who is injured.
I guess the governmental subdivision who employs the police --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So what, we should wait for, assuming that we might consider -- re-reconsider the exclusionary rule we should not do so until majority of the State Legislatures had acted, or majority of the State Courts had acted providing a specific tort remedy with a minimum amount of recovery, is that your suggestion?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I am suggesting --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I do not understand that?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That you could impose that in an opinion to make an incentive for state legislatures to move ahead and do this --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Where the state provides an alternative remedy then the Mapp against Ohio is out?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I believe that it could be done by this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Would not you -- would not it be your guess that every state in the union, including Alaska and Hawaii probably have such a tort remedy right now?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Not with any minimum recovery, I think that is the problem with most of them as people are not materially injured very much in this cases.
So they do not even bother the tort remedy because they might get a few dollars back and it would not be worth it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you suggesting there be a minimum recovery even, what -- first of all there has to be a finding of liability, does not it?
And then normally recovery is -- is key to the amount of damage.

You are suggesting of what, punitive damages, that a state must create a cause of action and allow for minimum punitive damages before the exclusionary rule should be reconsidered at least with respect to that state, is that what you are saying?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: It would be a form of those, Your Honor, yes.
A punitive damages I guess you --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- trouble damages plus attorneys’ fees, some sort of approach?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor and of course I am not advocating that in this case as far as a search warrant.
I think that this Court should not impose exclusionary rule in cases where, as I have mentioned earlier, search in -- under search warrant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How to enact with a warrant?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct, I do not believe that the -- unless there is some showing of collusion or fraud or something like that or the police actually lied in their affidavit or something in that nature, perjury.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) and disconnected from the police department in town?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Well, that is what they are in our case, I do not know how many --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is the situation I am talking about?
Can you localize it with police at all?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: There is no connection.
He is supposed to be interpose between the police and the public.

He, I believe that if someone were to be -- if some sort of a sanction ought to be imposed, it ought to be imposed on the magistrate, we should do away on the absolute protection that magistrate has in this type of case, which I believe is a court-made rule.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you suggesting that a magistrate be what, criminally of civilly liable, for doing what?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I am suggesting that a magistrate who is grossly negligent, that should have a some sort of liability or else his employers, yes and remove the immunity, the absolute immunity that magistrates now enjoy.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible) judicial immunity, would it not?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: It would cut across, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: (Voice overlap) in several cases?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I believe it be one possibility at least that an alternative rather to say that we are trying to deter the police who cannot possibly understand all of the intricacies and the certainties of the law.
Also the -- a lot of prosecutors do not understand the intricacies and the certainties of the law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You were going to make two points on this, you have made one now and your second one you have only about two or three minutes left.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I am sorry, but time got away from me, Your Honor.

The other point which I strongly urge this Court to adopt was the, I believe I can refer to this -- the easiest the court rule know what I am talking about is Mr. Justice Powell’s concurring opinion in Schneckloth versus Bustamonte that the Federal Courts not consider search and seizure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: (Inaudible) need not consider the form of --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Pardon, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: We agree on you on that, we need not consider the argument you have just made about modification of the rule?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: You need to consider?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: We would not need to consider it.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Oh! The one I have just made.
Well, I think that two could work together in some cases, it is rather a fall-back position, but I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which is the fall-back position according to you?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: The first argument.

The -- I believe that the second argument is based on; (a) that the violation of the Fourth Amendment is connected with a collar book claim of innocence, plus an opportunity to be heard in the State Court and to err these issues.

Now, I cannot conceive right off where second issue would need to be but there could be a possibility I suppose where the petitioner is claiming that the Fourth Amendment resulted in being unjustly convicted because he was innocent and he had a valid opportunity to contest it, and yet it was under a search warrant.
And if we did not adopt the first issue then he would still be able to bring it up under the invalid search warrant, in those cases only however.
But of course nobody here wants an innocent man convicted, I believe that is a point that should be allowed to continue and I believe everybody would agree with that in 2254 cases.

That -- this -- in summary then I would urge the Court to or I would say that we agree wholeheartedly with the concurring opinion in Schneckloth and with Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Harlan, Justice Harlan in the Kaufman case in the dissent.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Peek who came back into the act and testified that he indeed was the fellow who carried --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Mr. Peek testified on behalf of the state against Mr. Rice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They had arranged that he and -- the respondent here had arranged this booby trap suitcase that killed the policeman that you have described earlier.
Have you not, you are not making a harmless error argument?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: I must take it that your argument concedes that the Eight Circuit opinion is the proper one based on opinions of this Court?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I am not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: No, you make a point in your brief that makes it a valid search?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: -- in my brief which I have not argued, which I think this, I think the Eight Circuit --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: That indicates that the Eight Circuit opinion is out of line with anything decided here?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: The Eight Circuit is out of line in comparing the case with Langford versus Gilstone (ph) and also with saying that the police their exigent circumstances argument by going for a search warrant.

It is trying to take one for the other, you know, a trade-off of some type and they did leave a cordon around the empty house and I do -- I do not see how they can say that we lost exigent circumstances argument.

And thirdly, I think that the court misconstrued the Hayden case by saying that the police had have probable cause to believe that the person they were looking where there at the very time they entered the premises.

Because in Warden versus Hayden, even though they knew the person where in there they did not know that -- they did not have probable cause to open the washing machine lid where they found the weapon, and nevertheless that was sustained.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Kammerlohr.
Mr. Cunningham.

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

In the assignment of duties between counsel, in our case my colleague J. Patrick Green from Omaha, Nebraska was to have presented the oral argument and he has been incapacitated yesterday by severe attack of influenza.
I propose to deal with three points in the argument for the Court and be able to respond to questions from you, and in this order.

First, we think it of primary importance to deal with the question added to the grant of the petition for certiorari on 30th June, last year to whip whether the constitutional validity of the search and seizure performed by the Omaha police under the circumstances of this case is judicially cognizable under the 28 U.S.C 2254.

Almost in identical language on that same day, June 30 in Powell versus Stone, the court again added that question to the grant of certiorari and asked the parties involved, both to brief and to argue those questions, and so I propose to deal with that question first.

Secondly, I would like to deal with the need for Federal Review at lower court level federal constitutional questions, and by lower court level, I mean both the United States District Courts and the Circuit Courts of Appeal; with questions presented by state prisoners under 28 U.S.C 2254, in seeking petitions for habeas -- writs of habeas corpus.
Thirdly, I would like to present arguments regarding the standards that should be used by either state or federal courts to determine a constitutional validity of the search in this case.

Addressing myself to the first question, and transmitting any discussion of the facts which I think were brought out to some extent by counsel for the petitioner, I could deal with those in questions if the court so desires.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there relevance -- significantly relevant facts that have been omitted?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I think, Your Honor, when we take the record in its totality, including and placing the special stress upon the careful hearings -- evidentiary hearings in the Federal District Court in Lincoln, Nebraska before Judge Warren Urbam (ph), all of which is before the Court that we then have the total facts of the case.

But absent those two evidentiary hearings in March and July of 1974, before Judge Urbam granted the writ of habeas corpus, I think the Court would have had, had it come on direct review in an inadequate record before it.
So it supplemented then by those evidentiary hearings --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: They are all in (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: They are, Your Honor.
The relevant portions of them from the, yes.
Dealing then with the question of cognizability that the Court has asked us to brief and argue, we have to ask ourselves whether habeas corpus should be available.

This was raised of course in the concurring opinion in Schneckloth versus Bustamonte and there, when the Court -- when Justice Powell writing the concurring opinion, cites in footnote 16, Professor Amsterdam on certain finality interests that are to be -- that were to be concerned with in attempting to limit the Federal Collateral Review.
Justice Powell, realizes of course that Professor Amsterdam was talking about Federal Collateral Review for federal prisoners and not state prisoners --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That was the covenant (ph) case?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right, and Professor Amsterdam was very careful I think to make the point that he did not think that those considerations need apply to state prisoners in seeking federal collateral review of their claims, based upon Federal Constitutional violations.

The next year in 1965, Professor Amsterdam wrote a considerably longer and exhaustive article, criminal prosecutions affecting federally guaranteed civil rights, discussing removal there and habeas corpus petitions to avoid state court actions.

And I understand him to argue from that law review article the need there is, especially in state court proceedings, for some sort of federal monitoring at Federal District Court and Circuit Court level of the application of Federal Constitutional standard's defect situations.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course, this question could not have arisen before the decision in Mapp against the United States?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No, You Honor, no.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Except in a Rochin type situation?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And Mapp was decided when, about 1961?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: 1961, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And this question could not have possibly have risen until then and the Mapp opinion and I do not, I only read it recently, was four members of the Court joined it and the fifth, Justice Black, joined it only on the basis that involved compulsory self incrimination rather than purely a Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
But I take it that ever since then --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It was followed?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It has been followed and that the Circuit Courts have consistently applied it and the Federal District Courts, and so is this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But this all, this problem could not have arisen, and therefore, at the earliest it goes back to the decision in Mapp against the United States?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Indeed, Your Honor, yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then there was a conflict I gather on the Circuits after Mapp, as to whether or not this kind of a claim of Fourth Amendment claim, type claim, was available on Federal habeas corpus in reviewing a state conviction?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that was never, it was rather only rather implicitly resolved in this court was not it, because Kaufman involved a federal review of a federal conviction?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And it was not until, what case --?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I would say, Your Honor, in this Court’s treatment of Linkletter, this Court took from the Fifth Circuit in 1963 a habeas corpus case and in 1965, this Court took jurisdiction in Linkletter versus Walker and decided the case on its merits.
This Court could not have taken jurisdiction if there had not been jurisdiction in the courts below.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible) the court dealt with -- in Linkletter was its retroactivity?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: True enough.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The retroactivity of Mapp?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: True.
But it was a habeas corpus case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It could not have -- so that was just, it was implicitly a sub silentio if you will, adopted this rule by this Court without any explanation or explication or maybe realization?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Other District Courts, the District Courts of Appeal for example in Thornton versus the United States, the District Court of Columbia realized the distinction there was between a federal prisoner seeking federal review and a state prisoner, and allowing, in the opinion in that court, that state prisoners should have this device of reviewing a state conviction against them.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Cunningham, I suppose you could turn that argument around in view of all that we have said about comity and federalism, in cases like Younger and Osche (ph), and say that even though it is perfectly proper to have a federal collateral review of a federal conviction within a unitary system, perhaps the same principle ought not to be -- ought not to obtain where you are talking about a federal system with a federal court reviewing a state conviction?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I know how sensitive that the court must be to questions of comity like that, and I have read your opinion for the Court in Huffman versus Pursue, seeing what I could get from it and although I read two paragraphs and a very careful footnote, I still could be led to the conclusion that, Your Honor decided or there writing for the Court, allowed that if indeed there would be subsequent criminal prosecution, which at that time was threatened, that if a federal constitutional claim was in question that the proper time to review it would have been in collateral federal habeas corpus review of a state court conviction later on, but not to stop the process before it began.
And so, I have construed Huffman versus Pursue to say at least that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, certainly one would not necessarily treat all constitutional claims the same I suppose, but, that is perhaps right to counsel and that type of thing might be treated differently than Fourth Amendment.

All I am suggesting is that while certainly by the argument you make that it is more important when a Federal Court is reviewing a state conviction than when a Federal Court reviews a federal conviction, you can say just the opposite in view of the federalism considerations?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: True enough, but I would think that it is easy to understand that the State Court's primary allegiance could be to the enforcement of their own criminal law.
They stand responsible to do that and to review questions of state law and their own criminal statutes and the imposition of them and in matters that come before them, correctly or not.

But that Federal Courts are to remove from that if we are to guarantee federal supremacy of the federal law, are better circumstanced to look dispassionately upon a question that might involve an alleged violation of federal constitutional standards.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that statement has been made many times, including an opinions of this court, so you are more or less in good company, but does not then -- on what basis can one denigrate the State Courts of this Country in that way, to say that they do not have the same kind of understanding of the federal constitution, nor that they, if they understand it, they are reluctant to follow where their understanding leads?

That may once have been true in parts of the country a hundred years ago and it may have even been true more recently in other parts of the country, but what basis is there for making that kind of an assumption?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: To make such a broad indictment I think, Your Honor, would be irresponsible.
I do not want to believe that a single state court judge would set out maliciously to deprive anyone of a state court -- of a federally constitution -- a federally guaranteed constitutional right.

And yet, when I look for example, if this Court could refer to page 117, I believe of the respondents brief, we attempted to -- 119, excuse me, at footnote 5, we attempted to take the record of the State Supreme Court in Nebraska, in reviewing whether or not a warrant, search warrant was sufficient in a State Supreme Court.

And the Court will note there that in a number of occasions, the warrant was sustained by the State Supreme Court, that certiorari was denied on direct review by this Court and that on Federal Collateral review, the Eight Circuit Court of Appeals had found the warrant to be insufficient.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And why does that mean, that does not necessarily mean that the Eight Circuit was right and the Supreme Court of Nebraska wrong, does it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I could not argue that, Your Honor, but for example from 1961, post Mapp, when I conducted that search of cases, I find only one time that the State Supreme Court of Nebraska held a warrant to be insufficient and that was in 1975 in State versus Kelos (ph), where there was a laps of nine months between the facts alleged to establish probable cause in the issuance --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Is not it irrelevant statistic, the number of times that state trial courts have held warrants insufficient, those that were probably not appealed?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right, and that would be difficult to find, Your Honor.
And --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: You are dealing with very, very sketchy information is what I am suggesting when you just point to one Supreme Court opinion?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: True enough.

But for example, with my new specificity in this case, we see what a State Supreme Court and State Lower Court did with a warrant, so wanting in probable causes to leave no doubt in the mind of four Federal Court Judges in very careful opinions and exhausting -- exhaustive, painstaking evidentiary hearings to find that there simply was no basis for the warrant that was based, quite frankly as the officer testified upon his speculation.
That is neither reasonable, good faith nor probable cause.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your footnote that you have just referred to, establishes just one thing and that is that the Eight Circuit is a little more final than the Supreme Court of Nebraska because it is subsequent, does it really establish anything else at all?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It does I think, Your Honor, and that is the point before that I was making when I said that I would want the facts in this case amplified by what carefully was led out in testimonies, warrant testimony, affidavits, with an opportunity to cross-examine in the lower district court and that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) that had, there not been habeas remedy available in this case, and the respondent here were limited to direct review in this Court.
You are suggesting I gather that there would have been no record upon which we could properly have evaluated the merit of the Fourth Amendment --

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Indeed, and then if we are, Your Honor, to take away federal habeas corpus review under 2254 at the lower district court and circuit court level and to impose that duty upon an already burdened Supreme Court in terms of direct review, add to that an inadequate factual presentation or record --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Does not Nebraska have a motion to suppress proceeding where you could make the same sort of factual join that was ultimately made before Judge Urbam?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I believe indeed, there was such a hearing in this case, and I believe that the officer, or the impartial magistrate who issued the warrant then held a hearing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But he was a municipal court judge in Douglas County, that would not be the Judge before whom a case was tried, was it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I believe there was preliminary hearing and that he had occasion to review the warrant that he had issued.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, does the defendant have a right to renew the claim in the District Court, the State District Court where it is being tried?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor and I believe that all stages of the proceedings, the lawyers who were then representing him urged that motion to suppress and unsuccessfully.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, why should not he have had to make a factual showing at that time?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I certainly -- were I the State Court Judge and knowing that some sort of direct review was possible would want to have had a complete record, but I submit that the record was only completed for one reason or another and I know not why really when it came to the Federal District Court and Judge Urbam began to ask questions, like the questions that were answered very candidly at page 54, 55 and 56 of the respondent’s brief.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) state court?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) the case from, from Nebraska case being Nebraska actually?
I do not know whether the situation has changed.

One of the problems as I recall the trouble was then, was that too many States no longer -- did not yet have adequate collateral procedures because I remember Nebraska adopted one, three or four days, before case Nebraska was to be argued here and I do not know how its function since, I do not if what you tell us about this case, at least to this case it has not functioned too effectively?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It seems not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well (Inaudible) towards, then the Fourth Amendment issue has been once presented to the state courts, it is not -- a lot of states would not let you in their collateral proceeding just to take up an issue that has already been presented to its courts, is not that true in Nebraska?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Your question again, Your Honor, I am sorry.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose a suppression motion has been made and the Fourth Amendment issue has been passed upon by Nebraska Trial Court, and the claim has been rejected, and that judgment was affirmed in the Nebraska Supreme Court, state collateral proceedings are not then available, I take it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And, for exhaustion purposes it is not necessary to attempt to --?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No, not under the decisions of this Court.
The respondent had a right to go --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Indeed.
And did --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Once the state court has dealt with the issue, that is enough for the, federally?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It is true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well I gather then (Inaudible) the prospect is that in Nebraska we are not like we are the only court, only federal court, to review the federal constitutional claim.
We are not like to ever to get a record adequately to do that?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It certainly would not happen in this case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about a motion to suppress?
Excuse me, excuse me, I guess it depends on how you -- on how you look at the record that has been made in the state court?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I suppose one has to think about who conducted the hearings and the length of time, the remove there was from the emotive situation within which --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The Congress has established some rule as to when on federal collateral you have a hearing and you have to find some, supposedly find some defects in the state procedure before you proceed with the federal hearing, but if you do find those defects that is -- that is the benchmark for when you have a federal hearing, is that right?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) understood you, I thought you have said you could bring the exact same question again in the state court?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I would take it by a motion to suppress you could and if you could have --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: If you could have an evidentiary hearing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I suppose so, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And all of that would be in the record, we would have the exact same record we have got now?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I am not sure of that, Your Honor and I cannot be because what accounts for the testimony then that led to the issue on the search warrant, which the court has in the appendix at page 10, and the subsequent testimony of First Sergeant Fifer (ph) and then Lieutenant, and then --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) you have done in the suppression here?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It was not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) it was not, I said could if?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: If -- the same questions might be asked if the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything on this record that could not have been put in on motion to suppress?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Other than what I would say would be the candor of the officers who testified at the evidentiary hearing and said that it was based upon speculation.
It appears in the search warrant, not upon speculation, but sworn testimony furnishing probable cause.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: On the testimony in the suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but reviewed by a state court not by a federal court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It is reviewed by this court?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: If -- if you had an adequate record before you.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I say, could you or could you not have an adequate record?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: If they gave candid answers, Your Honor, yes?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What kind of answers would be less, more or less candid before the United States District Judge as compared with a State Court Judge of Nebraska?
Does not this depend on the lawyer more than on the judicial officer?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Perhaps to some extent, Your Honor, and the thoroughness with which he conducts an examination and yet I note that in answer to a question, by Judge Urbam, the officer who had before furnished the information, which led to the issuance of the search warrant said in answer to this question; “Did you have any report from anyone that Dwaine Peek was then inside the Rice house or had been inside the Rice house that day” and this is at page 54, his answer, “No Sir, the only thing we had was a speculation because it was a known house of that particular group and he was a member of that group and it was a place where he might possibly be.”
That is a wanting in good faith, reasonableness or probable cause that I think it took everyone by surprise at that hearing.
Whether or not --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But Urbam’s cross examination was a little more effective than defense counsel’s cross examination in the state courts?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Precisely, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that good as the system or is it the subjective factors of the idiosyncrasies and talents of the lawyer?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It might have been an accident of history or chance in this particular case, but nonetheless upon questioning, that answer was elicited from this officer.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What page?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Page 54, Your Honor, the respondent’s --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of your brief?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: The respondent’s brief.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If that judge had been on the state court, everything would have been alright?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: [Laughter] and elicited that question and that answer, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible) if this hearing had had the same scope than the State proceeding, then maybe the State Supreme Court would have decided the case the same way the Eight Circuit did?
We do not know, do we?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: We do not and we would have to speculate on that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) going out only to this system --

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: -- holding the inadequacy and everything else to the state procedure.

If the only Federal Court, if the only Federal Court to review the federal constitutional claim is this Court, if that is the system, what bearing if any the valid or nature of our discretionary jurisdiction have on its inadequacy as a system?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I would, if sitting where you were, be terribly worried that I would have inadequate records before me, that already pressed by work that will be pressed by more work, that I might, by a decision, take up jurisdiction that has been given by the constitution to Congress, that I would have to make a break with four or five decisions passed on by this Court and relied upon by countless litigants and that anything so cataclysmic changing the scope of habeas corpus could be better be done by well considered program legislation dealing with all those things.

If Congress wants to change the scope of habeas corpus in the hearing, in lower federal courts, this Court, Congress and the Constitution seems to guarantee and has up until this point, then it should be done by Congress that this Court --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The unarticulated premise of your whole position, I take it must be, but you tell me if that is not so, that the case presented by this record, where a man who has set a booby trap with dynamite in a suitcase, in pursuit of his own objectives, obviously criminal if we believe this record, is to get off scotfree and that that is an appropriate price to pay for mistakes in a warrant application or in the granting of that application by a judicial officer in Nebraska.
hat that is a reasonable and an appropriate price to pay and if that is the only way that we can accomplish that result; is that a fair statement of the, what underlies your position?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I would not say that.
I would say in answer to that you have touched upon the point raised initially in Justice Powell’s concurring opinion in Schneckloth, which is, is there a colorable claim of innocence.
The State of Nebraska has said that no claim, much less colorable, had ever been made by the defendant, the respondent in this case in any real way.
That has been a matter of tremendous concern to him and to his lawyers.

Justice Powell, in the concurring opinion in Schneckloth says, at page 257, that guilt or innocence had never been part of the consideration, the proper consideration in granting habeas corpus or not and at page 115 and 116 of the respondent’s brief, we discussed that your repeated attempts, and especially in the fourth footnote at those pages, the repeated attempts by the defendant to claim his innocence, there is in the record before this court a confession to that suitcase bombing by Dwaine Peek, who later recanted his confession and then named David Rice and Edward Poindexter who happened to be the President and Minister of Information of the local Black Panther Party.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Testified against them in the trial?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: And he at that time was under first degree murder charges and subsequent to the trial saying that no deal had been made, was treated as a juvenile delinquent and has not been seen since.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: 17 years old at that time, was he not?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, now taking the whole record, however, as it was accepted by the Jury and in the Trial Courts --

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes Sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it not a fair statement that this man, if you adopt Justice Cardozo’s statement, is to go free because of the constable blunder, or is not that fair?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I understand, I am familiar with from People versus Defore, Your Honor, but I would say that the man is not to be imprisoned if the trial at which he was tried was wanting in federal constitutional guarantees, if the trial was unfair.
In July of 1974, the District Court in Lincoln said that he must be retried or let go within 90 days.

All of those mandates were stated by the Eight Circuit, the Eight Circuit Court affirmed, and so for 19 months, so the petition for habeas corpus has been granted and we know that this man has in the judgment of four Federal Court Judges have been tried unfairly, that the issue then innocence is still open.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: By the standards that have existed up to this time on the exclusionary doctrine?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Indeed, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But if the fundamental proposition of the validity of the exclusionary doctrine is found and determined now, not to be warranted by the constitution, then the ball bounces the other way, does not it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is Parts II and III --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or in the alternative in what the Attorney General described as one of his alternative positions, if that is an issue that cannot be raised in federal habeas corpus at all, then I am sure the result follows?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: In line with the comments of the Chief Justice, is it your view that the exclusionary rule is compelled by the constitution?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: It is traditionally created of course, Your Honor, and it gives effect to the Fourth Amendment.
I believe it is compelled.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: If Congress is going to take it away procedurally by denying federal habeas corpus, then I think that that is for Congress to do.

But I think that for example, when a court allows evidence to be placed before it, that they know has been seized in contravention of the constitution, that we approach something very much like Shelly versus Kramer (ph), that the Court -- that the State, if it be a state prosecution, is in some way in complicity in allowing illegal activity to be become the basis for a prosecution.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) what we have said in Calandra, with respect to the constitutional status of the exclusionary rule?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And is it your view that the constitution requires that that rule be enforced fully with every guide to the circumstances, have a technical evaluation of the Fourth Amendment maybe?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: As a general proposition, yes.
But even in the fact--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Any and all circumstances, the constitution requires that evidence illegally seized because of the defective warrant or otherwise, cannot be employed, or admitted in the trial?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I think that is the only realistic thing because --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Any basis in that in history of our Country or prior to Mapp, any basis whatever?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Unless it be Shelly versus Kramer, in which we do not want the Court acting through its judicial arm --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible) certainly suggested your answer, it could have been decided the way it was, unless it was constitutional, although prior to Mapp, as my brother Powell has pointed -- implied in his -- in his question under -- under the regime of Weekes against the United States, it was always thought to be a ministerial rule of evidence.

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: But this court has a notion --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it was made constitutional, it had to be or it could not have been imposed upon the States.
It had to be something beyond this court’s supervisory power?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: And then the decisions in Katz begin to --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Safe Streets Act of course it is congressional, but has not Congress enacted the exclusionary rule in the Safe Streets Act both as to violations of an Act by state officials as well as by federal officials?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I would think so.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Your rationale is the correct one, can you, that is the Shelly versus Kramer approach, can you possibly justify the limitation on standing have it only the defendant who can raise the issue, would it not be necessary under that rationale that the point be available to the defendant, even though it was some third parties’ rights who were invaded by the search?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right, indeed in this case, Your Honor, the codefendant, David Rice has sought now unsuccessfully in the lower federal district court before the same Judge Warren Urbam, to raise the point about the unconstitutionality of the search and Judge Urbam has held that he did not have the requisite standing to raise the issue over the introduction of the evidence in a common trial against him of that evidence that was --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Holding maybe correct under Alderman, who would be inconsistent with your analysis?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You have suggested I think that this had, that the exclusionary rule had something to do with a fair trial and I think some of my colleagues implicitly accepted that suggestion, that at least so long as the exclusionary rule existed it had something to do with a fair trial.
Do you really think so?I never understood so.

I had always thought that it had to do with quite a different constitutional value, i.e. enforcement of the protections of the Fourth Amendment which by their terms have nothing to do with a trial, fair or unfair, they have to do with unreasonable searches and seizures and in so far as a probative, relevant material evidence is excluded from a trial that leads to unfairness rather than fairness, does not it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I would, You Honor --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because anything that impairs the search for truth impairs the search for justice and certainly anything that excludes, any rule that excludes relevant material, prohibitive evidence impairs the fairness of a trial because it impairs the full disclosure that a trial is supposed to accomplish, does not it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes.
Your Honor, I would not want to read the Fourth Amendment just by itself.

I would want to include the Fifth Amendment as well and say that the fairness of the hearing is going to be measured, not just by whether or not there has been a technical Fourth Amendment violation, but whether or not the whole trial, including the introduction at the evidence, the opportunity to cross-examine the people who introduce the evidence and all of the procedural safeguards for Due Process --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Compulsory of self-incrimination part of it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Or to Due Process, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or both?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Both.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Certainly the Eighth Circuit did not make any finding that there had been any independent Fifth Amendment Violation?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
Just a straight violation of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, are you contending that they should have made such a finding?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No, I think their opinion as it stands is perfectly adequate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But I, just to go back, I thought the whole point of the Linkletter, or at least a big part of the point of the Linkletter opinion, was that the exclusionary rule did not have anything to do with the fairness of a trial and in so far as it did have anything to do with a fairness of a trial, the exclusionary rule impaired the fairness of a trial?
Was not that point of the Linkletter opinion, in saying that the Mapp rule was not to be retroactive?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but I cannot see that the introduction into evidence in any proceeding, State or Federal --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Probative material evidence, (Voice Overlap) evidence that would clearly be admissible, except because of the way it was obtained by the prosecutor?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, because I regard, Your Honor, the totality of the process, including the trial and subsequent appeals, all of them, whenever allowed, to be part and parcel of the whole process to determine guilt or innocence and that until that be, until that course be run, we do not know whether we have something that is relevant or irrelevant to that issue.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Cunningham, Mr. Justice Stewart has given rise to one view and I would not undertake to say whether it is the majority view or not of the function of a trial, that is a search for truth, but are you not by implication articulating the contrary view that the trial in a criminal case is a search for admissible truth, admissible truth, not truth in the abstract?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I would want to say that any legal proceeding in its best aspect is precisely a search for truth.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That and except then the -- one of these two alternatives is that then surely you must agree with Justice Stewart that the exclusionary rule frustrates, defeats the search for truth as this case so richly demonstrates?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: If the subsequent hearings had not been held in this case, and the Federal Court had had not had revealed to it the real circumstances that lay behind the issuance, the application for an issuance of the search warrant, we would have no check upon this whole procedure and I cannot believe that the state --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: (Inaudible) procedure, not on substance, it is a check on procedure to seek to it that the only evidence that comes in is evidence acquired in accordance with constitution as construed by this Court?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So that as a result, ultimately, Justice Cardozo’s prophecy came true that on some occasions, the Federal Courts have excluded the actual evidence of the body of the murder victim because of the way in which the police learned the location of the concealed body, is that not true?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
