turn.text: That has happened, Your Honor and I think the Eight Circuit Court of Appeals faced that issue squarely at the end of their opinion when they said that we consider it necessary to point out that the record discloses a widespread search for the suspect Peek and Poindexter, which events at least a negligent disregard by the Omaha Police for constitutional rights of not only petitioner, but possibly other citizens as well.
Such a police search is at least reminiscent of police conduct condemned in Langeford versus Gilstone (ph).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Have to do with the core of this case?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I think, Your Honor, they said that though they found evidence, some evidence of guilt, the whole procedure because of the introduction of this evidence on an invalid warrant, invalidated the whole proceeding and that in order to be fair, one has to go back and try the case without the introduction at the evidence -- of this illegally seized evidence.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Dynamite and the caps and all that sort of thing?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
It is entirely possible that that dynamite could have been planted.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The dynamite fragments in the cuts of his pants planted too?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Could have been, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That is quite a different question whether it was illegally seized.
I mean, there is no connection between the claim that it might have been planted and the claim that it was illegally seized, is there?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Collaboration was necessary for an admitted accomplice in the murder, Dwaine Peek and collaboration was found in what later proved to be, according to the District Court and the Circuit Court of Appeals, an illegal and unconstitutional search, but it furnished the collaboration for the State Court in affirming that conviction.
Quite simply collaboration was needed for Dwaine Peek and it came as the result of an illegal search.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: (inaudible) you, but this is a very important case and you are very well prepared on arguing it, very well indeed.
I want to come back to question I have asked you as to whether Congress had authority to change the exclusionary rule which you view as required by the constitution.
If I understood your answer correctly, you have said that Congress could change the habeas corpus jurisdiction of the Federal Courts.

I myself do not think it is necessary to do that for this purpose, but put that aside, are you saying that Congress have no authority to modify in any respect or to revoke the exclusionary rule in the federal courts?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, I have to say that they had the power to do that.
Would they have to --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The constitutional requirement?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: My question is would they have to amend the constitution to do it?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right, right, I realize that --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) there cannot be a constitutional amendment to change a judge-made rule, that was not even extended to the states until 1961?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Which is, and this Court’s decisions putting it as part and parcel of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And you read, you find all of this in the language of the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: [Laughter] no, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible) Mapp against Ohio?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: This -- other decisions of this Court and the extension of the right of privacy too in your subsequent decisions.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Four Justices at that time, but more than four since then have said it is not a constitutional requirement, in Calandra for example.

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is it constitutional requirement, I suppose it is really no different than the right to counsel which has developed over the years that is also constitutionally compelled, is not it?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: As well as other constitutional rights that we have taken from the bill of rights, but not mention specifically --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) is what I am suggesting?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: The right to privacy, the right to freedom of association, things like that that the Court has seen and interpreted from the constitution.
One final thing I would remiss --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Have the trier of facts in litigation to an opportunity to consider the most relevant evidence on the issue of truth which you say is the object of trial?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The other, which one?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Privacy.

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Privacy --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Both --

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I think in Katz for example, when we said that the evidence might have been tremendously relevant, but there was a rightful expectation of privacy and although there had not been a physical intrusion, that right of privacy was sufficiently broad to be protected by the introduction of admittedly relevant evidence and so too in this Court’s decision in Rochin versus California.
Everyone knew that he had illegally seized or possessed morphine in his stomach.
It was the way they went about getting it that shocked the conscience of the court and led us to say that Due Process guarantees at least that kind of a proceeding free from that kind of taint.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Telling the truth is really not always the objective, the primary objective in litigation in our Courts?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: No it should be, Your Honor, it should be.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Trials, devote more time to trying the police than they do the defendant?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: [Laughter] an unfortunate distraction, but to leave them less than wholly cross-examined I think would be sort of remiss too.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think your reference to Rochin, inevitably brings up the question of Schmerberg case, where it did not shock the conscience of the court to put a needle in the man’s veins and withdraw a sufficient amount of blood to determine the alcoholic intake of the man at that period.

So that -- does that not suggest that even at the risk of oversimplification that the same processes which brought new light on the constitution, let us as say 20 years ago, might bring new light on the constitution today?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Indeed, the constitution I think must continue to grow and to be interpreted.

I remember, Justice Douglas in an answer, in a colloquy over a paper called, “Two Faces of Federalism” saying that he found it difficult to describe Due Process, but Justice Holmes had approached it one time, in a letter not an opinion, in which he said if what happened generally makes you want to vomit is usually a deprivation of Due Process of law, but some have stronger stomachs than others.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) reserve the situation -- procedures which would could make you want to vomit?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right, exactly and if medical science has advanced to the point where we can take from a person unconscious a sample of blood and achieve some sort of evidence, then perhaps you know, we had a tolerance for that at time and may not later.

The only thing I would like to say, Your Honor, and I know that we have had ample time here, is that, if this Court sees fit either to cut down the extent of the writ of habeas corpus, the reach of it, and if they see fit or see fit to adopt new rules for a search, reasonableness, good faith of the policemen, whatever it may be, if the Court does this, my client must not be penalized for taking the decisions that were the law at that time seriously, nor must the Eight Circuit Court of Appeals be penalized for taking the decisions of this Court seriously because a proceeding has been conducted and to know tell him at this stage of the game that he has pursued the wrong avenue --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Penalty when we reverse another court Mr. Cunningham, [laughs] (inaudible) might just welcome the ultimate justice?

turn.speaker: william_c_cunningham
turn.label: Mr. William C. Cunningham
turn.text: Right.
Yes, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Let me have a minute, Your Honor, just to clarify a couple of points.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: First I would like to pint out that even though the counsel claims that Mr. Rice makes some claims of innocence, what Mr. Justice Powell was talking about and Mr. Black -- Justice Black and Harlan and Stewart in the Bustamante case and the Kaufman cases was a claim under the Fourth Amendment.

We are talking about the Fourth Amendment in that if habeas corpus were allowed in Fourth Amendment, it would reveal a colorable claim of innocence, then they should preserve it in those cases, but not a claim of innocence based on something that is not under the Fourth Amendment.
I do not believe that is the whole or the suggestion of those opinions --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Justice Harlan advocated the claim of innocence position in Kaufman?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I do not think that is true?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I believe he did not limit it to that, he did not limit it to that at least, but I am just suggesting that it means a claim of innocence under the Fourth Amendment not a claim of innocence, say for insufficient evidence that the jury has already ruled against it.
It is which what he is arguing here that maybe the jury was wrong, but not would be remedied any by a Fourth Amendment claim and habeas corpus.

Another point I would like to point out to the Court the motion for suppression in this case was handled by the federal -- by the State District Court, not the magistrate who issued the search warrant.
The magistrate issued a search warrant then the case came to the trial court level, which is a jury trial level in Nebraska.
And the motion was made in that trial court, the same court who later held the trial, the same judge.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Under your Nebraska practice, is it the custom is to make the motion before trial?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not at the time (Voice Overlap) the proper of the evidence?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Although I suppose it could be done at the later time too.
You have objected to the evidence?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: We have a procedure for a interlocutory appeal from a motion to suppress to the State Supreme Court, and then I believe it can still, but I am not certain -- if it can still be brought up at the time of trial.
I would certainly think so --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But the custom is to file a motion of suppress before the commencement of the trial?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is correct, and then --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that appeal is before the judge who is going to try the case or --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, generally speaking --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- or at least one of the --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: It has to be one of the District Court Judges.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) cold case in Nebraska.
Nebraska adopted a counterpart of 2255 as its post conviction procedure, did it not?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Is that still the one?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is still the one we have, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And in this could there have been a proceeding under that remedy after the Supreme Court affirmed the denial of the motion to suppress?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Not as concerning the search warrant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice overlap) or is it because the state does not have a counterpart of the rule of the Kaufman case.
Does the State say we are not going to consider Fourth Amendment type claims on collateral?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No, it would be because the Supreme Court of Nebraska had already decided the issue.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And your collateral of remedy, state collateral remedy is limited to new questions?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: New questions, which have not been before the court.
Now, they might have brought up the search without the warrant -- in collateral proceedings, they did not.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The Supreme Court decision on the issue is res judicata --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- and not -- as a consequence of that the collateral attack is barred on traditional grounds?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I believe that is what would happen if someone brought back in the District Court a collateral proceeding, the District Judge would merely say this has all been decided by the State Supreme Court and the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You do not have a federal habeas corpus, you do not have a res judicata.

In other words, no 2255, something -- the Fourth Amendment claim might have been in a Federal District Court and considered by the, by United States Court of Appeals, nonetheless, unless I am mistaken, their remedy under Section 2255 is available to reconsider that claim, would it not, under the Kaufman rule?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Under the Kaufman case if the identical question had been to this Court and ruled adversely, I do not --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: United States Court of Appeals where the conviction was affirmed, we are getting pretty far field?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: I do not see how it could, but --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What is Nebraska rule if there had not been a motion to suppress at the criminal trial?
Could the defendant raise the issue in the collateral proceeding in a state court, the Fourth Amendment question?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because it is the fact that there was actually the question litigated that forecloses it.
It would not waive it by dealing to make the motion --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: At least, now Judge Urbam -- it is -- you are correct to the fact it was litigated.

Now, the other question, a search without the search warrant, which I brought up in the State Supreme Court, was not litigated there because they held the search warrant was valid, but Judge Urbam said that the fact the we briefed it in State Supreme Court was sufficient exhaustion in Federal Courts, which I disagree with also.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You seem to assume, I was under the impression that the magistrate who issued the warrant was the same judicial officer who passed on the suppression motion, and you say that that is not correct?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: That is incorrect.

And another point that I think Mr. Cunningham brought up which highlights the bad part of having a habeas -- federal habeas corpus sitting years later is that when the evidentiary hearing was held before Judge Urbam some four years after the fact and the evidence is not clear at that time in the officer’s mind, they have had hundreds of cases probably since the time and one Lieutenant Perry testified at that evidentiary hearing four years later that he -- that Dwaine Peek had told them before they went to the Rice premises that the bomb was constructed there at the Rice premises and that Dwaine, his brother, had told him this.
Judge Urbam, and he -- then Judge Urbam is doing the questioning and he said, well how do you know that?

And he said, I was present when Officer Foxel (ph) interrogated Dwaine Peek and Judge Urbam then looked on the, a sheet they have at the police station that shows who was present at the interrogation, and Lieutenant Perry’s name did not appear on there.

So Judge Urbam arrived at the conclusion that Lieutenant Perry was perjuring himself, and I think he put a lot of weight on this and this is just one of the bad things that happened by hiring before you litter.
I say that Lieutenant Perry might have learned about in a number of ways and forgot how he learned about it, and it did not necessarily perjure himself.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible) hearing in the state court and the record made, and the motion to suppress denial that a federal habeas corpus court is not supposed to hold a hearing of its own, unless as the statute requires it finds some defect in state court proceeding.

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what defect did Judge Urbam found -- find in the state court of suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: He did not -- he got in to the, he got in to it on the search without a warrant issue -- without a search warrant issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible) hearing unless there was some --

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: He did not hold an evidentiary hearing on the search warrant issue.

Once he found that the search warrant was invalid, the affidavit for the search warrant was invalid, then we raised issues that nevertheless the police had a right to be on the premises, then he held an evidentiary hearing on that question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There had never been a hearing on that in the state court?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No, Your Honor because the Supreme Court never reached that issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible) the same that he was, he was -- he really cannot be saying that he was retreading ground that the state court had gone over because it had never gone over that ground?

turn.speaker: melvin_kent_kammerlohr
turn.label: Mr. Melvin Kent Kammerlohr
turn.text: No, I am just, I am merely saying this shows that the police officer’s memories may get kind of dim after four years.
Thank you, Your Honors.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Cunningham, thank you Mr. Kammerlohr.
The case is submitted.
